Group

A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Monoid Homomorphism

Let $G, G^{\'prime}$ be monoids with corresponding unit elements $e$ and $e^{\'prime}$. A monoid homomorphism $\varphi: G \longrightarrow G^{\'prime}$ is a map $\varphi$ from $G$ to $G^{\'prime}$ such that (i) $\varphi(e)=e^{\'prime}$, (ii) $\varphi(a b)=\varphi(a) \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Division Ring
A ring R is called a division ring or a skew field if R is not the zero ring and every nonzero element of R is a unit (R* = R - {0}).
Ring Monomorphism
A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a monomorphism if it is injective.
Ring Automorphism
An automorphism of a ring $R$ is an isomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R$.
Submodule
Submodules of an A-module M are defined similarly to subspaces in vector spaces, where a submodule N of M is a subset that is closed under the operations of M.
Length of an A-module
The length l_A(M) of an A-module M is defined as the supremum of all numbers l such that there is a chain of submodules 0 subsetneq M_1 subsetneq M_2 subsetneq ... subsetneq M_l = M of length l.
Algebraic Element

Given a field extension $K \subset L$, an element $\alpha \in L$ is called algebraic over $K$ if it satisfies an algebraic equation over $K$, i.e., an equation $\alpha^{n}+c_{1} \alpha^{n-1}+\ldots+c_{n}=0$ with coefficients $c_{1}, \ldots, c_{n} \in K$.
Algebraic subset

An algebraic subset of \(\bar{K}^{n}\) defined over \(K\) is the set of common zeros in \(\bar{K}^{n}\) of the polynomials belonging to a subset \(E\) of the polynomial ring \(K[X]=K\left[X_{1}, \ldots, X_{n}\right]\). It is denoted as \(V(E)\).
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Alternating Group

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Map/Function
A map is a relationship between two sets that associates every element in one set(domain) to exactly one element in another set (codomain).
Definition_Association_Analysis

Implied_Association_Relationships.Explanation: A group is defined as a monoid with additional properties. Therefore, the concept of a monoid must be defined to understand what a group is.
A monoid homomorphism is a specific type of map between two monoids. Therefore, the concept of a map must be defined to understand what a monoid homomorphism is.
A ring automorphism is a specific type of isomorphism, which is a bijective homomorphism. Therefore, the concept of a ring homomorphism must be defined to understand what a ring automorphism is.
The length of an A-module is defined in terms of submodules. Therefore, the concept of a submodule must be defined to understand what the length of an A-module is.
An algebraic element is defined in terms of a field extension. Therefore, the concept of a field extension must be defined to understand what an algebraic element is.
An algebraic subset is defined in terms of polynomials and polynomial rings. Therefore, the concept of a polynomial ring must be defined to understand what an algebraic subset is.
The Galois group of a field extension is defined in terms of field automorphisms. Therefore, the concept of a field automorphism must be defined to understand what a Galois group is.
